author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: The Senate returns to a complicated agenda, seeking to pass infrastructure and other economic priorities.
description: Democratic leaders have mapped out a monthlong sprint for senators, warning them to prepare for late nights and even the cancellation of part of their beloved August recess.
content: The Senate returned to Washington on Monday after a two-week recess facing a pile of complicated legislative work and key deadlines looming in the push to enact President Biden’s far-reaching economic agenda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yotam Ottolenghi
title: Ottolenghi’s Formula for Easy, Delicious Dishes
description: If you have something fresh, something flavorful and something in need of using up, you’re most of the way to a meal, Yotam Ottolenghi writes.
content: LONDON — I often think of recipes as being like stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Guillain-Barré and Vaccines: What You Need to Know
description: The link between the rare neurological disorder and the Johnson & Johnson Covid-19 vaccine may be real, but the risk appears to be very small.
content: Johnson & Johnson’s beleaguered Covid-19 vaccine may be associated with a small increased risk of Guillain–Barré syndrome, a rare but potentially serious neurological condition, federal officials said on Monday. The Food and Drug Administration has added a warning about the potential side effect to its fact sheets about the vaccine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Long Island Farm Adds Classes
description: Kerber’s Farm in Huntington, N.Y., is now offering cooking and beekeeping courses, among others, at its two-acre farm.
content: Nick Voulgaris III, who grew up in Huntington, N.Y., remembers going as a child to Kerber’s Farm, a local farm and store that was founded in 1941. About 10 years ago, the owners planned to sell it to a developer. Mr. Voulgaris, who had become a restaurateur and caterer, bought it, renovated it and reopened it. “I had a nostalgic connection,” he said. On a mere two acres he raises organic vegetables, flowers, chickens, ducks, pigs, goats. There’s also a farm store, with a bakery and a cafe known for chicken potpie. “It’s our own mini-ecosystem,” he said. He has just added a farm school, with classes for children and adults in growing and harvesting vegetables, beekeeping, raising livestock, sustainability, and, in one of the barns on the property, cooking. Classes are mostly $35 to $50 and soon will be available for streaming, free.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: A top U.S. general in Afghanistan steps down as the war ends and the Taliban sweep across much of the country.
description: KABUL, Afghanistan — The top American general in Afghanistan stepped down on Monday, a symbolic moment as the United States nears the end of its 20-year-old war and Taliban fighters sweep across the country.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The top American general in Afghanistan stepped down on Monday, a symbolic moment as the United States nears the end of its 20-year-old war and Taliban fighters sweep across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiroko Tabuchi
title: E.P.A. Approved Toxic Chemicals for Fracking a Decade Ago, New Files Show
description: The compounds can form PFAS, also known as “forever chemicals,” which have been linked to cancer and birth defects. The E.P.A. approvals came despite the agency’s own concerns about toxicity.
content: For much of the past decade, oil companies engaged in drilling and fracking have been allowed to pump into the ground chemicals that, over time, can break down into toxic substances known as PFAS — a class of long-lasting compounds known to pose a threat to people and wildlife — according to internal documents from the Environmental Protection Agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lawrence Ware
title: ‘Boyz N the Hood’ at 30: A Vivid Examination of Racism at Work
description: The director John Singleton uses the experiences of a father and son, Tre and Furious, to depict how a Black community comes undone.
content: When John Singleton’s first film, “Boyz N the Hood,” was released on July 12, 1991, it immediately made him a household name in many Black communities across the country. The movie was so well received that my mother decided to take me to see the film in the theater.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz and Erin Woo
title: Hello, Content Creators. Silicon Valley’s Investors Want to Meet You.
description: The online influencer culture is starting to draw serious interest from big venture capital firms. But the real money could be in digital tools, not the personalities.
content: Last summer, Tucker Schreiber, a 28-year-old co-founder of a start-up called Combo that was building a video editing platform, noticed a lot more emails in his inbox. Though his company had no employees and no products, and hadn’t even said it was looking for money, investors were sending him a stream of messages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Kate Cherkis
title: Tourists in N.Y.C. Marvel at a Cleaner, Less-Crowded Subway
description: In a newly reopened New York City, travel and hotel costs are still relatively low, enticing some young people, retirees and families to make the trip.
content: The last time Richard McKee rode the New York City subway, John F. Kennedy was in the White House. Now retired and vaccinated, he flew here in June from Northern California and headed underground with a camera around his neck to photograph the murals and installations in the subway stations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: South African Military Is Called In to Quell Violence
description: Protests over the imprisonment of Jacob Zuma have escalated into looting and other destructive lawlessness fed in part by poverty and scant opportunity.
content: JOHANNESBURG — Declaring that the nation is reeling from public violence “rarely seen before in the history of our democracy,” South Africa’s president on Monday deployed the military in an effort to quell the escalating civil unrest that has led to several deaths, tens of millions of dollars in damages to businesses and the disruption of the nation’s coronavirus vaccination program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacquelynn Kerubo
title: How Black Women Can Interpret Those Scary Health Statistics
description: Doomsday headlines are nothing new. But over time they can damage your mental health if you’re not careful.
content: When Halona Black lost her 49-year-old mother to breast cancer in 2006, she was sure she was destined to suffer the same fate. She had seen the data: Black women were 40 percent more likely to die of breast cancer than white women, especially those with close relatives who had been diagnosed with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anahad O'Connor
title: Alcohol Abuse Is on the Rise, but Doctors Too Often Fail to Treat It
description: People with alcohol use disorder are often seen in clinics and hospitals, but medical professionals too often ignore the condition.
content: Like many people who struggle to control their drinking, Andy Mathisen tried a lot of ways to cut back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Seasonal Desserts That Surprise
description: “Wild Sweetness,” a book from the writer Thalia Ho, is an elegant recipe collection for the changing seasons.
content: The chapters in “Wild Sweetness,” a dessert cookbook by Thalia Ho, an award-winning food blogger who lives in Australia, unfold according to seasons, but without your typical peach pie in summer or pumpkin for fall. It’s a subtler, more elegant and personal collection, threaded throughout with chocolate. Several fancy confections are included, but most of the cakes tend to be tidy loaves or single layers, perhaps with some crumble or glaze on top and begging for a glass of sweet wine. There are several brownies and blondies, some uncommonly scented with figs and bay leaves; a brownie made with cocoa is a simple delight. Most cookies are easy, made by scooping batter onto baking sheets, and include chocolate chunk with some buckwheat flour for an earthy counterpoint. The author’s photographs are lovely. The recipes I tried all needed a bit more baking time than called for (my ovens are precise, recently calibrated), so the cook should pay more attention to Ms. Ho’s guidelines for testing doneness than to the clock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
title: Thailand will give health workers a mix of Chinese and Western vaccines.
description: The move comes after more than 600 medical employees who had received two doses of the Sinovac vaccine became infected.
content: Thailand said on Monday that health care workers who had received the coronavirus vaccine made by Sinovac of China would also be inoculated with the Oxford-AstraZeneca or Pfizer-BioNTech shots to give them greater protection as concerns grow about more transmissible variants as well as about the waning immunity provided by Sinovac.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Nick Corasaniti
title: Texas Democrats Flee State to Highlight G.O.P. Voting Restrictions
description: The move is an attempt to block Republicans from passing a new voting bill while also applying pressure on Congress to pass legislation at the federal level.
content: STERLING, Va. — Texas Democrats fled the state on Monday in a last-ditch effort to prevent the passage of a restrictive new voting law by the Republican-controlled Legislature, heading to Washington to draw national attention to their cause.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: In Game 3, Antetokounmpo Didn’t Do All of the Work
description: The Bucks played well even without their star on the floor, and cut the Suns’ lead to two games to one.
content: MILWAUKEE — With about 3:44 left in the first half, the Milwaukee Bucks were leading the Phoenix Suns by 8 points in Game 3 of the N.B.A. finals after a basket by Giannis Antetokounmpo. It was a crucial opportunity to build momentum heading into halftime, and Bucks Coach Mike Budenholzer pulled Antetokounmpo from the game to try to buy his superstar some rest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman
title: ‘I’m Not Just a Kid Who Did Something Wrong’
description: A high school football player in Texas became infamous when he did the unthinkable, leveling a referee. With grace from the ref, the player is seeking a new start.
content: EDINBURG, Texas — Emmanuel Durón, 19, was scheduled to leave for college last Friday. A surprise pool party was arranged to send him off to restore a ruined football career. But the trade school he plans to attend in Atlanta was still trying to secure a field for its inaugural season. So Durón will have to wait at least a few more weeks before starting a new life, aiming to become someone other than a forever villain who attacked a referee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Catch and Kill’ and the MLB All-Star Game
description: HBO airs a documentary about Ronan Farrow’s book “Catch and Kill,” and the MLB hosts its 91st annual All-Star Game.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, July 12 — July 18. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tressie McMillan Cottom
title: Savala Nolan Takes a Hard Look at the White Gaze and Its Blind Spots
description: The essays in “Don’t Let It Get You Down” explore the in-betweenness of race, class and the size of a woman’s body.
content: DON’T LET IT GET YOU DOWN Essays on Race, Gender, and the BodyBy Savala Nolan
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: The Slog Is Over. Now a New Slog Begins.
description: The players who battled for the Euro 2020 title will walk away from the tournament and right into a new season.
content: LONDON — Giorgio Chiellini and Leonardo Bonucci had a full day of activities planned. They left England in the small hours of Monday morning, and landed back in Rome together with the rest of Italy’s exultant and exhausted Euro 2020 champions not long after dawn. There, they presented the glinting, silver spoils of their campaign to their public. Chiellini was wearing a crown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: A Manager’s Son Had a Big Moment as a Bat Boy. Now He’s Going Pro.
description: Dusty Baker’s son, Darren, doesn’t remember nearly being run over at the 2002 World Series. But lessons from Dusty, and players he managed, have fashioned Darren into a throwback.
content: BERKELEY, Calif. — When the coronavirus pandemic shut down sports more than a year ago, Dusty Baker, who had just taken over as manager of the Houston Astros, left spring training and returned home to Granite Bay, Calif., just outside Sacramento. So, too, did his son Darren, when his baseball season — along with his in-person classes at the University of California, Berkeley — came to an abrupt end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter, Simon Romero and Eric Nagourney
title: Arrest in Haiti Assassination Leaves Some Baffled: ‘Nobody Ever Heard of Him’
description: Questions are swirling over the arrest of a doctor with ties to Florida described as playing a central role in the death of Haiti’s president, Jovenel Moïse.
content: As a sprawling multinational investigation into the assassination of Haiti’s president broadens, with suspects stretching from Colombia to Florida, the Haitian authorities have turned their focus to a little-known doctor who they said coveted the presidency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Shohei Ohtani Is Just the Star America’s Pastime Needs
description: This week the Angels star, one of the greatest spectacles in all of sports, will hit and pitch in the All-Star Game. He could not have timed his breakout season any better.
content: SEATTLE — As I type this from the lonely cheap seats in the lofty upper deck of T-Mobile Park, I’m still trying to digest what I just saw.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Chasing a Grand Slam: It’s Rarer Than You Think
description: Novak Djokovic has claimed this year’s Australian and French Opens and Wimbledon. Only the U.S. Open is left to be won. But no man has achieved a Grand Slam since 1969, and no woman since 1988.
content: Most fans know about the tennis Grand Slam: winning the Australian Open, French Open, Wimbledon and U.S. Open in the same calendar year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheri Fink
title: The Rationing of a Last-Resort Covid Treatment
description: While ventilator shortages have been largely averted in the U.S., this lifesaving therapy is scarce. How to choose which critically ill patients get it?
content: During a surge of coronavirus cases at Houston Methodist Hospital last summer, a patient in his 40s on a ventilator was declining. There was one more option, a last-resort treatment that can mechanically substitute for badly damaged lungs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: 20 Simple Sauces That Will Transform Any Meal
description: Quick from-scratch condiments, dressings, toppings and seasonings to make every dish — even the laziest snacks — taste special.
content: There’s the fantasy: cooking a party spread for friends, or even just dinner on any given night. And then there’s the reality: getting home late because of traffic or meetings that run long, or simply losing the motivation to make a whole meal from scratch because of the overwhelming desire to lie on the grass (or the couch) a little while longer. When that happens, a fridge filled with homemade sauces offers the promise of a nearly effortless meal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Helper in the Kitchen
description: Grime is a new hand soap that was born as a pandemic activity.
content: Forget sourdough or knitting. What the Californians Vanessa Erskine, a jewelry designer and avid gardener, and Langdon Taguiped, her partner and a cyclist, did during the pandemic was make soap. And now they’re selling it. Their goal was a soap that could tackle the grime on Ms. Erskine’s hands and the grease from assembling and maintaining bicycles on Mr. Taguiped’s, without many of the ingredients like dyes and sulfates commonly found in commercial cleaning agents. Their compact and effective gray blocks, each 1.9 ounces, are made mainly from coconut oil, sand, activated charcoal and fir needle oil. Sodium hydroxide, or lye, is there, too, a necessary grease-cutting ingredient that’s been used in soap since ancient times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Winning Junior Wimbledon Is ‘Crazy’, but It’s Still ‘Just the Juniors’
description: This year’s boys’ final, which featured two American teenagers, represented a surprising success for U.S. tennis as the sport desperately seeks another top men’s player.
content: WIMBLEDON, England — As Novak Djokovic and Matteo Berrettini played the first set of the Wimbledon men’s singles final Sunday afternoon on Centre Court, two young Americans were wrapping up the boys’ singles final, 100 yards and also a world away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: 13-Year-Old Boy, Believed to Be the Intended Target, Dies in Bronx Shooting
description: The boy was shot by a gunman who emerged from a passing vehicle in what the police called a gang-related attack.
content: A 13-year-old boy was shot and killed outside a cafe in the Bronx on Sunday afternoon in what police officials said they believed was a gang-related attack that targeted the boy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth La Ferla
title: Elizabeth Hurley Talks About Comedy and Swimsuits
description: Plus, how Sanford Biggers, TK Wonder and Jeffrey Banks navigated the pandemic.
content: The New York charity circuit has started to come back. Here is how some philanthropists and society figures spent their time and resources during the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: Michael Landy’s Art of Destruction
description: A new show by the British artist, who once gained fame by destroying everything he owned in an art installation, is again calling attention to the pervasiveness of consumerism and waste in modern life.
content: COLCHESTER, England — Michael Landy is a British artist best-known for a project in which he systematically inventoried all 7,227 of his personal possessions. Then systematically destroyed them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart Butler
title: Scattered Among the Himalaya, Glimpses of a Changing Tibet
description: An array of forces, including political suppression and the ubiquity of the internet, have made elements of traditional Tibetan lifestyles increasingly challenging.
content: I was sitting inside the dark, yak-hair tent of a nomad family in Ladakh, in the Indian Himalaya. Outside, some scruffy sheep searched for greenery among the cold and barren moonscape, and large raptors circled in the thermals. As we huddled around the hearth, the old man handed me a small glass of salty, yak-butter tea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Wall Street Sees Blowout Profits Ahead
description: Corporate leaders expect rosy company earnings, starting this week.
content: After closing the books on the second quarter, executives are the most positive they have ever been about the profits their companies are generating, according to data from FactSet. And that might be a good sign that bottom-line growth will continue even after the expected rebound from the pandemic economic plunge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: These Are the Eggs You Are Looking For
description: Dorie Greenspan wrote about the pleasures of classic oeuf mayonnaise.
content: Good morning. Dorie Greenspan has a lovely column in The New York Times Magazine this week devoted to the pleasures of oeuf mayonnaise (above), a classic appetizer of peeled boiled eggs under satiny mayonnaise that is so revered in France that there is a society there to protect its sanctity: the Association de sauvegarde de l’oeuf mayonnaise. “Le temps passe, les oeufs durent,” reads the tagline on their website. “Time passes, the eggs last.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Drake Bell Given Two Years of Probation in Child Endangerment Case
description: The former star of the Nickelodeon series “Drake & Josh” had pleaded guilty to two charges related to a girl he met online. She attended one of his concerts in 2017.
content: Jared Drake Bell, a former star of the Nickelodeon series “Drake & Josh,” was sentenced on Monday to two years of probation after pleading guilty to two charges against him relating to a girl he had met online and who attended one of his concerts in Cleveland in 2017.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: Even the Tuning Up Gets an Ovation as Tanglewood Reopens
description: The mood was festive as the Boston Symphony returned to its summer home for its first in-person performances since March 2020.
content: LENOX, Mass. — If you were brave enough, there was a time last summer when you could still turn into the drive of Tanglewood, the idyllic summer home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra here. There were the usual local teenagers to direct you to your parking space, one pointing the way every few yards; the usual state troopers, patrol cars idling, there to tip a hat; the usual flowers, lining the path through the pristine white gates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: As consumers fret about near-term inflation, the Fed is watching closely.
description: Inflation expectations jumped in a survey by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, as central bankers watch for signs that price gains will last.
content: Near-term consumer inflation expectations jumped to the highest level on record in a Federal Reserve Bank of New York survey, a sign that a pop in prices as the economy reopens from the pandemic is catching households’ attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: BioBonds Would Use Wall St. Tools to Fund Medical Research
description: Karen Petrou invented a new funding model for curing blindness. Proposed legislation aims to apply it to medical research more generally.
content: In the development of disease treatments, the stage between basic research and advanced clinical trials is known as “the valley of death.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Fire at Iraq Covid Hospital Kills at Least 39
description: The fire at a hospital in the southern city of Nasiriya also injured at least 20 and many patients were still missing, health officials and the police said Monday.
content: CAIRO — At least 39 people were killed and more than 20 injured in a fire at a coronavirus hospital in Nasiriya in southern Iraq, health officials and the police said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma and Mujib Mashal
title: Nepal Court Replaces Prime Minister After Months of Turbulence
description: Supporters of the recent prime minister, K.P. Sharma Oli, said they would not accept the ruling. But nearly two dozen members of his own party wanted him out.
content: KATHMANDU, Nepal — Nepal’s highest court on Monday stripped the prime minister of his duties and reinstated the Parliament that he had dissolved twice in recent months, opening a new chapter in the messy political conflict that has stagnated governance in the midst of a severe Covid crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Triple-digit temperatures and health warnings continued on Monday.
description: Despite some reprieve from record-high temperatures this weekend, the summer’s third heat wave, and accompanying health risks, raged on.
content: The Western United States continued to bake on Monday, with cities and entire counties across Central California and parts of Utah under excessive heat warnings and advisories, expected to reach at least 100 degrees and up to 114 degrees in some areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Florida, the Land of Gleaming Condos, Frets After Collapse
description: The high-rise condos along the Miami seashore long embodied the Florida dream of sunshine and prosperity. But the Champlain Towers South catastrophe is obscuring that vision.
content: SURFSIDE, Fla. — Modern Florida was built on condos like Champlain Towers South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Simon Romero
title: What were Colombian military vets doing in Haiti?
description: Colombia has one of the best-trained militaries in Latin America, and because of this, Colombian veterans are highly sought after by global security companies. They deploy them to faraway places like Yemen and Iraq, often paying far more than they could expect to earn in Colombia.
content: Colombia has one of the best-trained militaries in Latin America, and because of this, Colombian veterans are highly sought after by global security companies. They deploy them to faraway places like Yemen and Iraq, often paying far more than they could expect to earn in Colombia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corinne Purtill
title: For Years, Western Scientists Stigmatized Periods. We’re Living the Consequences.
description: Science had a late start collecting quality data on menstruation. The result is a persistent “knowledge gap” between what doctors know about female bodies and the comparatively greater amount they know about male bodies.
content: — Elinor Cleghorn, the author of “Unwell Women: Misdiagnosis and Myth in a Man-Made World.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Haiti is searching for answers almost a week after the assassination of its president.
content: Haiti is feverishly searching for answers after the assassination of President Jovenel Moïse last week, while the public remains skeptical of official narratives. Here are live updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: How the Drought Is Affecting California’s Crops
description: Monday: Consider the almond. Also: Mayor Eric Garcetti is set to go to India.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Beanbag Chairs
description: Yes, they’re back — and they don’t all look alike. Take these five, for instance.
content: Don’t assume you know what a beanbag chair looks — or feels — like, if the last time you sat on one was in a college dorm or a children’s playroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Israel allows those with weakened immune systems to get a third Pfizer-BioNTech shot.
description: The health ministry cited the rising infection rate as well as growing evidence that such people do not develop sufficient antibodies after two doses.
content: Israel’s Ministry of Health on Monday issued guidelines for administering a third shot of the two-dose Pfizer-BioNTech coronavirus vaccine to people with compromised immune systems, citing the rising infection rate in recent weeks as well as growing evidence that such people do not develop sufficient antibodies after two doses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green
title: Jane Kaufman, Artist Who Celebrated Women’s Work, Dies at 83
description: A leader of what became known as the Pattern and Decoration movement, she made screens, wall hangings and quilts — a radical act in an age of minimalism.
content: Jane Kaufman was making minimalist paintings in the early 1970s, spraying automobile paint on huge canvases. To be sure, the paint was sparkly, so the canvases shimmered — “lyrical abstraction” was how one reviewer described her art and that of others doing similar work — but they were firmly of their reductive minimalist moment. Hilton Kramer of The New York Times approved, giving Ms. Kaufman a nod as a “new abstractionist” in his mostly dismissive review of the Whitney Biennial in 1973.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Latin America Unrest Forces Biden to Confront Challenges to Democracy Close to Home
description: U.S. influence began waning in the region over the past decade, as successive administrations turned toward fighting terrorism in the Middle East.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden took office with bold warnings for Russia and China about human rights as he pressed democracies around the world to stand up against autocracy. But this week, he is facing a string of similar challenges in America’s neighborhood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: 6 Months After Riot, Capitol Police Face Multiple Crises
description: The department that protects Congress is damaged and depleted following the Jan. 6 assault, with funding, staffing and operational problems plaguing a deeply demoralized force.
content: WASHINGTON — As the mob pushed its way through the Capitol’s Crypt on Jan. 6, Officer James Blassingame was slammed back against a stone column and nearly overrun. He saw hate in the eyes of the rioters, hoisting Trump flags and “Make America Great Again” hats, as they urinated on the walls where American icons have served and called him racist slurs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A City’s Step Toward Reparations
description: How Evanston, Ill., became the first American city to approve a compensation program intended to address historical racism and discrimination.
content: For decades, the granting of racial reparations in the United States appeared to be a political nonstarter. Even self-described progressive politicians ran from the issue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Szalai
title: ‘The Man Who Hated Women’ Is Mostly About the Women He Hated
description: Amy Sohn’s new book is about a 19th-century moral crusader and the women whose work he targeted, including the suffragist Victoria C. Woodhull, the anarchist Emma Goldman and the birth control activist Margaret Sanger.
content: “The Man Who Hated Women,” the arresting title of Amy Sohn’s new book, would have been more fitting if the book were truly about the man who hated women. But Sohn’s narrative is less about Anthony Comstock — the self-styled moral crusader and chief architect of the Comstock Act of 1873, which made it a federal offense to send “obscene, lewd or lascivious” material through the mail — than it is about the targets of his hatred, the women themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: 9/11 Museum’s 20th-Anniversary Exhibitions Become Victims of Cuts
description: At an important vantage point in history, there will be no special shows looking back at the 2001 attacks, and critics say the museum keeps too tight a rein on the story.
content: The 9/11 Memorial & Museum in Lower Manhattan has dropped plans for special exhibitions commemorating the 20th anniversary of what was perhaps the most traumatic day in modern American history, museum officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Top U.S. General Steps Down in Afghanistan
description: Gen. Austin S. Miller is leaving as the United States prepares to end its two-decade war in Afghanistan, and as Taliban fighters sweep across much of the country.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The top American general in Afghanistan stepped down on Monday, a symbolic moment as the United States nears the end of its 20-year-old war and Taliban fighters sweep across the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Our Favorite Presidents You’ve Never Heard Of
description: Historical obscurity has its charms.
content: Bret Stephens: Gail, your last column reminded me that we share a peculiar obsession with obscure presidents: Franklin Pierce, Benjamin Harrison, his grandfather William Henry. I was a little disappointed that you had nothing to say about Chester Arthur. Was he too obscure to make the obscure list?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: This Camembert Is Made for a Cookout
description: This Hudson Valley cheese is given a barbecue rub by Murray’s Cheese as it ages.
content: This summer, over in the aging caves of Murray’s Cheese in Long Island City, Queens, they’ve been having some fun with Camembert. The affineurs have given it the barbecue treatment, with a rub of brown sugar and spices like smoked paprika, infusing the cheese with a hint of the backyard grill. The Camembert they’re treating this way is not the classic French cheese, but a satin-textured square from Old Chatham Sheepherding in the Hudson Valley, made with a blend of sheep and cow’s milk. It’s a fine partner for charcuterie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Barcelona Wants to Keep Lionel Messi. La Liga May Not Allow It.
description: Barcelona’s financial woes and the expiration of its star’s contract have left the club in a bind. And the only solution — about $200 million in salary cuts — won’t be easy.
content: When Lionel Messi stepped off the field late Saturday night after the final of the Copa América, the Argentina captain — one of the most celebrated athletes in history — was, at long last, a champion in his national colors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: The Durable Myth of Urban Hellholes
description: Why are politicians still contrasting rural virtue with urban vice?
content: Over the weekend J.D. Vance, the author of “Hillbilly Elegy” and now a Trumpist candidate for U.S. senator in Ohio, tweeted that he was planning a visit to New York, which he has heard is “disgusting and violent.” Vance, a graduate of Yale Law School who currently works as a venture capitalist, surely knows better. But he presumably hopes that Republican voters don’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Olivia Rodrigo Holds at No. 1 With ‘Sour’
description: The singer-songwriter’s debut album has now spent three weeks in the Billboard 200’s peak position.
content: This week on the music charts, Olivia Rodrigo’s “Sour” returns as the No. 1 album, while BTS’s song “Butter” closes in on her record for the year’s longest-running top single.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Gold
title: Jeanie Buss Is Laughing Through Her Pain
description: A series of personal and professional losses have challenged the Los Angeles Lakers’ owner in recent years. So she turned to stand-up comedy.
content: By the time she got to the microphone, the applause had subsided, and Jeanie Buss was faced with the scariest sound for a stand-up comedian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Voter Fraud Fraud
description: A Black man was praised for his willingness to vote. Now he faces criminal charges.
content: It was March 3, 2020, the day of the Democratic primary in Texas, and Hervis Rogers, a 62-year-old Black man, was intent on making his voice heard at the ballot box. He arrived at the polling place around 7 p.m. and joined the line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: Bank profits are poised to surge as the pandemic recedes.
description: The country’s biggest banks will report their quarterly earnings this week, reaping the benefits of an economy that’s returning to normal.
content: The nation’s biggest banks are about to report windfall profits as customers increase their spending and the economy bounces back from the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez and Ernesto Londoño
title: ‘Everyone Has a Tipping Point’: Hunger Fuels Cuba’s Protests
description: A day after a rare outbreak of anti-government protests in Cuba, the United States and Cuba traded sharp words.
content: Hospitals and pharmacies have run out of medicines as basic as penicillin and aspirin. Blackouts have become maddeningly frequent and agonizingly long. Cubans lucky enough to have foreign currency wait in line for hours for staples like beans and rice.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The (Not So?) Tentative Return of Live Music
description: A look at the challenges touring musicians faced over the last year, and how the industry is adjusting to the new normal.
content: Fewer industries felt a more specific and intense economic burden during the pandemic than live music. Venues went quiet. Musicians were stuck at home, with an occasional livestream to leaven the boredom (and financial strain). Though the federal government recently passed relief measures intended to stem the financial pain felt by performance venues, the rollout of the programs has been chaotic, leaving the industry not much better off than it was 16 months ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney
title: Emerging From Covid, Small Theaters in Los Angeles Face a New Challenge
description: A state law threatens to drive up labor costs for the city’s hand-to-mouth small theater scene as it tries to emerge from the pandemic.
content: LOS ANGELES — “And here she is, in all her glory.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: How Do You Stop Robocalls?
description: An F.C.C. rule that went into effect last month is meant to help put a stop to those relentless calls about your extended warranty, and others.
content: The calls look vaguely familiar, as if they could be coming from a neighbor’s phone. Sometimes they’re ominous warnings about your Social Security number. A friendly voice pretends to be concerned about the warranty on a car you don’t have.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Philipps
title: A Mission to Get a Forgotten Military Perspective
description: Looking at the withdrawal of U.S. forces in Afghanistan and in Vietnam nearly 50 years ago, a reporter sought to tell an overlooked part of history before it was too late.
content: Call it journalistic pessimism. This spring, even before President Biden announced the withdrawal of all U.S. forces from Afghanistan, I began to think about how Kabul might compare with Saigon just before it fell in 1975. Were there clear differences? Important similarities? Maybe even lessons to be learned?
source.name: The New York Times

title: Climate change is playing a role in the heat, drought and fires.
description: Heat waves are becoming hotter and more frequent.
content: As large swaths of the West dry out and burn, scientists say climate change is playing an increasing role in the earlier fire seasons, the deadly heat waves and the lack of water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: After months in limbo, Taiwan finally has a deal to acquire BioNTech shots.
description: The deal for 10 million vaccine doses eases a serious shortage on the self-ruling island, which has accused Beijing of interfering with previous efforts.
content: BioNTech on Monday announced a deal to provide 10 million doses of its coronavirus vaccine to Taiwan, easing a serious shortage there and ending months of deadlock stemming from the self-ruling island’s complicated relationship with China, which considers Taiwan part of its territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Phoebe Philo Is Returning to Fashion With Her Own Brand
description: The patron saint of designing for the female gaze is back.
content: Listen? Do you hear that? It is the intake of breath after thousands of women’s fashion prayers are finally answered. Phoebe Philo, the patron saint of dressing for the female gaze, the designer whose work convinced Joan Didion to pose for an ad and turned her customers into groupies, is returning to business. On her own terms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Rob Portman on Why the G.O.P. Should Team Up With Biden on Infrastructure
description: The Republican senator who is leading negotiations for his party on a bipartisan infrastructure plan says Republicans have nothing to lose and much to gain in cutting a deal with the president.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio and a three-decade veteran of Washington, helped lead the bipartisan negotiations that produced an infrastructure deal that has been endorsed by President Biden. But that may have been the easy part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naomi Skwarna
title: Debut Novels by Pik-Shuen Fung, Rahul Raina and Alex McElroy
description: New fiction ranges from a Chinese family divided across continents to the founding of a cult for rehabilitating toxic masculinity.
content: GHOST FOREST By Pik-Shuen Fung 257 pp. One World. $26.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roxanne Khamsi
title: Why the Most Unusual Covid Cases Matter
description: Rather than dismissed as flukes, unusual cases should be treated as bellwethers.
content: Like many people around the world and in Brazil where she lives, Parouhi Darakjian Kouyoumdjian became infected with the coronavirus last year; she had mild symptoms and recovered. But her case is remarkable: Ms. Kouyoumdjian is a centenarian.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: After Defeat, England’s Black Soccer Players Face a Racist Outburst
description: The social media bigotry, directed at three players who missed penalty kicks in the Euro 2020 final, was condemned by Prime Minister Boris Johnson and most everyone else.
content: LONDON — England wrapped its arms around its national soccer team the morning after its history-making run ended in heartbreaking defeat. But an ugly eruption of racist gibes against some of its young Black players was a reminder that not everyone glories in the diverse portrait of the country that this team reflects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shalini Venugopal Bhagat, Bhadra Sharma and Saif Hasnat
title: South Asian migrant workers are stranded as they wait for vaccines.
description: Thousands across the region have been left in limbo because of sluggish immunization campaigns, red tape and closed borders.
content: The pandemic has been a cruel blow for thousands of migrant workers in South Asia who are out of work or unable to return to their jobs abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How hot was it? Records fell across the West.
description: The temperatures this weekend weren’t just hot, they were record-breaking, including in Death Valley.
content: Last month was the hottest June in the country’s recorded history, and July continues to bring the heat. In Nevada and Colorado this past weekend, reported highs beat records set years ago, while California’s Death Valley might have reached a planetary peak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Andrew Lloyd Webber’s New Act: Activism
description: On questions of reopening, the theater impresario has become a surprising thorn in the British government’s side.
content: LONDON — Andrew Lloyd Webber, 73, has for decades been a household name in Britain for his flamboyant, quasi-operatic musicals. Now, he’s becoming known for something more unexpected: activism.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What can we expect the rest of the week?
description: The Western United States could continue to experience dangerously high temperatures for the next few days.
content: Although temperatures will drop this week from the record highs of recent days, they will remain in the danger zone in some places, with parts of California, Utah and Nevada reaching from 100 to 114 degrees on Monday and Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon
title: Vaccines, Haiti, Texas: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Defense Lawyers Move to Block Force-Feeding of Guantánamo Prisoner
description: The standoff began in June when a detainee accused of conspiring in the Sept. 11 attacks was placed in disciplinary status, away from the other prisoners, and stopped eating.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — One of the five men accused of conspiring in the Sept. 11 attacks is refusing to eat after being placed in isolation and has been told he could be force-fed, his lawyers said in a legal filing that asked a military court to intervene.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: E.U. Delays Digital Levy as Tax Talks Proceed
description: The postponement came as Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen arrived in Brussels to continue pushing for a global minimum tax.
content: BRUSSELS — The United States secured a diplomatic victory in Europe on Monday when European Union officials agreed to postpone their proposal for a digital levy that threatened to derail a global effort to crack down on tax havens.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Edwin Edwards, Flamboyant Louisiana Governor, Is Dead at 93
description: He served four terms, charmed voters with his escapades and survived a score of investigations before going to prison in 2002 for racketeering.
content: Edwin W. Edwards, the only four-term governor in Louisiana’s history, a swashbuckling rogue who charmed voters with his escapades and survived a score of grand jury investigations and two corruption trials before going to prison in 2002 for racketeering, died on Monday at his home in Gonzales, La. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Super Mario 64 Video Game Sells for $1.56 Million
description: The sale, to an anonymous bidder, set a record just two days after a copy of The Legend of Zelda sold for $870,000, according to Heritage Auctions.
content: An anonymous buyer has paid $1.56 million for a 25-year-old copy of Super Mario 64 in its original packaging, a record price for a video game, according to the auction house that sold it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: When School Is Voluntary
description: Many parents want to continue remote learning. It may not be so good for their children.
content: More than a century ago, U.S. states put in place laws requiring that children attend school. The guiding principle was that school mattered too much to children’s lives to be a matter of individual choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Italy’s victory over England.
content: Italy beat England in a penalty shootout to win the European soccer championship yesterday, breaking English hearts and dashing the country’s hopes of winning its first major title since the 1966 World Cup.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: W.H.O. Experts Seek Limits on Human Gene-Editing Experiments
description: The panel also called on countries to ensure that beneficial forms of genetic alteration be shared equitably.
content: A committee of experts working with the World Health Organization on Monday called on the nations of the world to set stronger limits on powerful methods of human gene editing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: As Republicans Take Aim at Voting, Democrats Search for a Response
description: A speech by President Biden on Tuesday could be a signal of how hard the Democrats will fight to protect voting rights.
content: WASHINGTON — The Democratic Party pledged millions for it last week, grass-roots groups are campaigning for it nationwide and, as recently as Friday, Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, said the fight for it had only begun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: A big opening for ‘Black Widow’ gives a taste of how theaters and streaming can coexist.
description: The long-delayed Marvel-Disney movie generated $80 million at the domestic box office and another $60 million on the Disney+ streaming platform.
content: There has been a lot of hand-wringing about the demise of movie theaters over the past year and a half, and for good reason. Most were closed for at least a few months during the height of the pandemic. Companies like the Walt Disney Company, NBCUniversal, WarnerMedia and Viacom have started to prioritize streaming for their films, in part to bolster subscriber interest in their own Netflix-style platforms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: With Italian Soccer Victory, ‘Brexit Completed’
description: It was inevitable that political score settling would be layered onto the Euro 2020 championship, and European fans and leaders took more than a little glee in denying England a chance for vindication.
content: ROME — At 12:06 a.m. local time on Monday, immediately after Italy’s goalie blocked a penalty kick to defeat England and become the soccer champions of Europe, Carlo Cottarelli, a prominent Italian economist sometimes mentioned as a potential prime minister, celebrated with a single word.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Margolies
title: When Scaffolding Hands Them Lemons, Developers Make Lemon Trees
description: Construction sheds are a necessary evil, meant to protect workers and passers-by. But recent efforts have reimagined them as experiential installations.
content: Under billowing, cloudlike fabric stretching the length of a football field, fake lemon trees with purple-and-blue trunks sprout from AstroTurf. Lemon slices the size of cafe tabletops are scattered about like oversize stone pavers, and knee-high plants bear halves of the citrus fruit cast in fiberglass resin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: A lockdown in Sydney, Australia, looks likely to be extended.
description: Officials in Sydney, Australia, warned on Monday that the city’s lockdown could be extended as an outbreak of the highly contagious Delta variant of the coronavirus showed no signs of slowing down.
content: Officials in Sydney, Australia, warned on Monday that the city’s lockdown could be extended as an outbreak of the highly contagious Delta variant of the coronavirus showed no signs of slowing down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The F.D.A. will warn that Johnson & Johnson’s vaccine can increase risk of a rare condition.
content: The F.D.A. is planning to warn that Johnson & Johnson’s coronavirus vaccine can lead to an increased risk of a rare neurological condition known as Guillain–Barré syndrome, according to people familiar with the decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Review: In ‘Seize the King,’ ‘Richard III’ Goes to Harlem
description: It’s a tale that Will Power intends as cautionary, with cycles of history and human violence in mind.
content: Have you been ravenous, lo these many shutdown months, for the layered richness of live theatrical design? The Classical Theater of Harlem has just the thing to sate your hunger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.6 Million Homes in California
description: A midcentury-modern house in Sierra Madre, a Tudor Revival in Burlingame and a Victorian cottage in Coronado.
content: Sierra Madre, a small city in the foothills of the San Gabriel Mountains, is known for its annual Wistaria Festival and its proximity to the Angeles National Forest. This house was designed in 1965 by Harlan H. Pedersen, a local architect, using rustic colors and materials that reflect its surroundings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason DeParle
title: Monthly Payments to Families With Children to Begin
description: The Biden administration will send up to $300 per child a month to most American families thanks to a temporary increase in the child tax credit that advocates hope to extend.
content: WASHINGTON — If all goes as planned, the Treasury Department will begin making a series of monthly payments in coming days to families with children, setting a milestone in social policy and intensifying a debate over whether to make the subsidies a permanent part of the American safety net.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Byron Berline, Master of the Bluegrass Fiddle, Dies at 77
description: His updated version of an old-timey approach enhanced recordings by everyone from Bill Monroe to the Rolling Stones.
content: Byron Berline, the acclaimed bluegrass fiddle player who expanded the vocabulary of his instrument while also establishing it as an integral voice in country-rock on recordings by Bob Dylan, the Rolling Stones and others, died on Saturday in Oklahoma City. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: The Pandemic Habit We Should Not Break
description: As we get back into the world and the germs that inhabit it, we shouldn’t drop the hand-washing habits so many us adopted in the Covid era.
content: After a year of obsessive 20-second hand-washings every time I touched something from outside my home, I think I should have stocked up on hand cream, not toilet paper, at the start of the pandemic. It was certainly not a good time for CVS to discontinue my favorite product, Healthy Hands lotion, which could have kept my skin from resembling sandpaper these many months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: To Help Haiti, Stop Trying to Save It
description: Treating people as helpless has a  way of making them so.
content: When it comes to Haiti, Joe Biden’s instincts are right: The best the United States can do is to do as little as possible — and, if possible, a bit less.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: William Smith, Action Star Known for His Onscreen Brawls, Dies at 88
description: In addition to his Hollywood legacy, the Missouri native was also a bodybuilder, a champion discus thrower and a published poet.
content: William Smith, an actor known for his portrayals of villains and his onscreen movie brawls, died on July 5 in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: With Shohei Ohtani, Baseball Embraces ‘Why Not?’
description: As his fellow All-Stars grapple with Ohtani’s brilliance, they focus on the difficult nature of his versatility. In a risk-averse game, he is an argument for going all in.
content: DENVER — Every All-Star knows the stress and the sacrifice that brought them here. Rising to the peak of a sport tends to require every bit of effort, mental and physical. None of them will say it came easily.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Medieval French Coins Unearthed in Poland? A Mystery Begins
description: Could a scavenger hunter’s find be a part of the lost booty once extorted by Vikings to spare Paris from ruin? A full-scale excavation may tell.
content: BISKUPIEC, Poland — During more than 10 years of tramping through fields and forests with a metal detector, a Polish treasure hunter has found the wreckage of an American-made Sherman tank, the scabbard of a French sword used by a soldier in Napoleon’s army, a Prussian helmet and many other relics of Europe’s bloody past.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Residents in California were urged to conserve power.
description: As Californians have retreated indoors, seeking relief from the dangerously high temperatures, pressure has grown on the state’s electrical system, with officials now relying on backup power and urging people to conserve energy or risk rolling blackouts.
content: As Californians have retreated indoors, seeking relief from the dangerously high temperatures, pressure has grown on the state’s electrical system, with officials now relying on backup power and urging people to conserve energy or risk rolling blackouts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Saharan Dust Plume Blows Past Florida Into Texas
description: The weather phenomenon, which is common this time of year, has reached parts of Texas, creating hazy skies and perhaps some respiratory challenges.
content: Over the past few weeks, the United States has experienced unprecedented heat, a hurricane and tornadoes. Now, the country is set to see another weather phenomenon as a plume of dust from the Sahara drifts across the Atlantic Ocean, creating hazy sunsets and possibly respiratory issues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: Biden called his own speech boring recently, highlighting his tendency toward ‘explainer in chief.’
description: CRYSTAL LAKE, Ill. — Even President Biden thought he had been ponderous.
content: CRYSTAL LAKE, Ill. — Even President Biden thought he had been ponderous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: For Spike Lee, the Secret to Surviving Cannes Is Sleep (and Cool Clothes)
description: The glamorous film festival can also be arduous, but here’s how Lee and his fellow Cannes jurors are staying alert.
content: CANNES, France — Sprawled out over two weeks, Cannes can be an awfully overwhelming film festival. There are so many movies to see and so many glamorous events to go to that you could easily burn out — or worse, fall asleep during a future Palme d’Or winner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: It’s Situation Normal for U.S. Diplomats in Kabul, Despite Taliban Gains
description: The Biden administration is determined to keep a diplomatic presence in Afghanistan as the 20-year conflict comes to a close.
content: WASHINGTON — A Taliban rampage across Afghanistan is stoking fears that extremists could overrun the capital, Kabul, and force the evacuation of the U.S. Embassy. But inside the building, American diplomats emerging from a monthlong coronavirus lockdown are returning to business as usual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: F.D.A. Attaches Warning of Rare Nerve Syndrome to Johnson & Johnson Vaccine
description: Federal regulators concluded that the risk of developing the syndrome was low, and that the benefits of the vaccine still strongly outweigh it.
content: The Food and Drug Administration warned on Monday that Johnson & Johnson’s coronavirus vaccine can lead to an increased risk of a rare neurological condition known as Guillain–Barré syndrome, another setback for a vaccine that has largely been sidelined in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle and Mark Landler
title: ‘Freedom Day’ Coming to England, Ready or Not
description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson is set on lifting all restrictions on July 19 despite a surge in cases. Critics predict mass confusion.
content: LONDON — With coronavirus infections surging yet again, Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Monday urged Britons to keep wearing face masks in crowded, indoor spaces even as he promised to unlock England’s economy next week and lift almost all virus-related restrictions.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Wildfires were burning more than a million acres across the western U.S. and Canada.
description: Wildfires left their mark across the Western landscape this weekend, scorching more than a million acres in the United States and Canada. The intensity of the blazes, at such an early stage in the wildfire season, was called “unprecedented” by officials.
content: Wildfires left their mark across the Western landscape this weekend, scorching more than a million acres in the United States and Canada. The intensity of the blazes, at such an early stage in the wildfire season, was called “unprecedented” by officials.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: July 12, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 12, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siddhartha Mitter
title: Foundations to Support U.S. Latino Artists With Cash Grants
description: The Latinx Artist Fellowships are backed by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation and the Ford Foundation, and the first 15 fellows will each receive $50,000.
content: Two major foundations have joined forces to make unrestricted cash grants to artists of Latin American or Caribbean descent born or living in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Two Jordanians Sentenced to Prison in Plot Against Monarchy
description: A closed court sentenced a former confidant to Jordan’s king and adviser to the Saudi crown prince, along with a cousin of the monarch, to 15 years in prison.
content: After a trial rife with accusations of betrayal within Jordan’s royal family and interference by Saudi Arabia, a Jordanian court on Monday sentenced King Abdullah II’s former adviser and a cousin of the monarch to 15 years in prison for trying to destabilize the kingdom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: With the Delta Variant, Do I Need a Covid Booster Shot?
description: Although studies of a third dose are underway, experts agree that the vaccines are still working well, even against the Delta variant, and that booster shots are not necessary right now.
content: Covid-19 booster shots are in the news, but chances are that Americans won’t be getting an extra shot in the arm any time soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: A Festival Has a Monumental Premiere (and Some Other Operas, Too)
description: At the Aix-en-Provence Festival in France, it was hard for even beloved classics to live up to the elegant intensity of Kaija Saariaho’s “Innocence.”
content: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France — I mean it as high praise when I say that at this summer’s edition of the Aix-en-Provence Festival, none of the operas come close to Kaija Saariaho’s “Innocence,” which premiered here on July 3.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Village Fought Off Virus, but Neighbors Didn’t. It’s a Bad Sign for India.
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 12, 2021.
content: “Last year, if you had told somebody that we have over 1,000 deaths a day — and the real number might be five times that — they would have said that is completely unacceptable. This year, people are as if ‘It’s just 1,000 deaths a day. It’s fine. We can manage with that.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Maheshwari
title: Nordstrom, Eyeing 20-Somethings, Strikes Deal With the Online Giant Asos
description: Nordstrom hopes a partnership with the online fashion behemoth can attract younger shopper back to its stores and its website.
content: Nordstrom, one of many national retailers battered by the pandemic, has added a new arrow to its quiver as it fights an uphill battle to get customers, particularly young ones, back: It is teaming up with Asos, the online fashion behemoth.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Rum Rebranded, From Martinique
description: Rhum Clément’s blanc agricole is made from sugar cane.
content: Most white, unaged rums are made industrially, that is, from the molasses byproduct of sugar refining. But not Rhum Clément on the island of Martinique in the West Indies. All of its rums, including the whites, are labeled agricole, meaning agricultural, distilled from the fresh-pressed and fermented juice of sugar cane. The company has now renamed its basic white rum as blanc agricole and with leaner packaging, among other efforts, has reduced the price. It’s 80 proof, a blend of several varieties of sugar cane and while assertive has floral and citric notes. Rhum Clément also makes another one, slightly mellower in flavor: the Canne Bleue, 100 proof, from a single type of sugar cane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Trump Suits Against Tech Giants Face Steep First Amendment Hurdles
description: A unanimous 1974 Supreme Court decision said newspapers could not be forced to publish replies from politicians they had criticized.
content: WASHINGTON — Whatever else might be said about the curious lawsuits filed last week by former President Donald J. Trump, in which he accused three big tech companies of violating his First Amendment rights by denying him access to their platforms, it is fitting that he sued in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai and Alexandra Stevenson
title: Hong Kong Migrants Seek Fresh Start in U.K. After Crackdown
description: Many who have left the city say they feel less like refugees than trailblazers, eager to build a new home after watching their old one slowly transform under Beijing.
content: LONDON — Lin Kwong had a good life in Hong Kong. She taught sports management part time at a college and chaired an amateur drama club. Her young son, Chee Yin, was doted on by his grandparents. She had friends and favorite restaurants. But in February, she made the difficult decision to leave it all behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Badger
title: Covid Didn’t Kill Cities. Why Was That Prophecy So Alluring?
description: A distrust of urban life has persisted in America, finding expression in different ways over time.
content: From the moment U.S. coronavirus cases emerged in the Seattle area and then devastated New York City last spring, sweeping predictions about the future of city life followed. Density was done for. An exodus to the suburbs and small towns would ensue. Transit would become obsolete. The appeal of a yard and a home office would trump demand for bustling urban spaces. And Zoom would replace the in-person connections that give big cities their economic might.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: You Can’t Take It With You, but You Can Put It in Storage
description: In rural places where there are few actual homes, there are now more teeny tiny warehouses than you would believe, all for stuff that won’t fit anywhere else.
content: NASHVILLE — Back when my children were small, I felt like I was drowning in an ocean of things. Diapers. Pacifiers. Booster seats. Storybooks. Action figures. Legos, hobbling anyone foolish enough to go barefoot in the dark. It dawned on me once that the whole house could burn to the ground and I would feel no great regret. As long as my family was safe, I could stand on the curb and watch the flames leaping into the night sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Workshop for the Cronut King
description: Dominique Ansel has opened a new kitchen in NoMad churning out a bevy of burnished breakfast pastries.
content: The pastry chef Dominique Ansel has a knack for Viennoiseries, another name for croissants and their well-burnished everyday cousins. His Cronut aptly demonstrates his talent and imagination. Now, with his new NoMad workshop, he is delving deeper into the possibilities offered by the genre. “For 12 years working in Paris, it was all I was doing, and I saw how creative you could be,” he said. His idea is to produce classics like a crisp-skinned croissant with a properly honeycombed interior, but also to disrupt the category. So there is a delicious, flaky multigrain croissant, and one made with olive oil, garlic and rosemary. He’s making a type of brioche scented with orange and star anise, another pastry filled with rice pudding and huckleberry jam, and crunchy gougères oozing Comté cheese. The space is just a kitchen with a sales counter, so plan to eat your purchases at the few tables outside or soon after you get them home; Mr. Ansel says their shelf-life is brief. He will soon install a small chocolate kitchen in part of the space.
source.name: The New York Times
